Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law and common-law landlord-tenant principles, a landlord owes to a residential tenant the covenant of quiet enjoyment — an implied promise that the tenant will have possession and use of the leased premises free from substantial interference by the landlord or by conditions the landlord has a duty to correct.

State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Mi.raw_text: State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Mi.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations impose minimum standards for fitness for human habitation and public-health-based obligations that bear on a landlord’s responsibility for conditions that affect habitability and the safety and health of tenants — including the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation), and Massachusetts public-health statutes concerning nuisances and sanitary conditions.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations impose minimum standards for fitness for human habitation and public-health-based obligations that bear on a landlord’s responsibility for conditions that affect habitability and the safety and health of tenants — including the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation), and Massachusetts public-health statutes concerning nuisances and sanitary conditions.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations impose minimum standards for fitness for human habitation and public-health-based obligations that bear on a landlord’s responsibility for conditions that affect habitability and the safety and health of tenants — including the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation), and Massachusetts public-health statutes concerning nuisances and sanitary conditions.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations impose minimum standards for fitness for human habitation and public-health-based obligations that bear on a landlord’s responsibility for conditions that affect habitability and the safety and health of tenants — including the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation), and Massachusetts public-health statutes concerning nuisances and sanitary conditions.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: A landlord who fails to maintain premises in a habitable condition and who fails to remedy conditions that substantially impair a tenant’s use and enjoyment may be liable to the tenant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and for related damages.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes an implied warranty of habitability and allows a tenant to recover damages measured by the diminished rental value, but it does so under contract/warranty and rent-abatement theories, not under the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The discussion of quiet enjoyment appears only in a footnote explaining constructive eviction doctrine and expressly focuses the present case on failure to maintain habitability, not on quiet enjoyment claims. Thus, the case supports landlord liability for breach of an implied warranty of habitability and related rent and damage remedies, but it does not hold that such failures constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment itself.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “We have concluded that a warranty of habitability is implied by law in residential leases in this state and that the breach of such a warranty may be raised as a defense in an unlawful detainer action. Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. … If the trial court does find a breach of implied warranty, the court must then determine the extent of the damages flowing from this breach.”

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: A landlord who fails to maintain premises in a habitable condition and who fails to remedy conditions that substantially impair a tenant’s use and enjoyment may be liable to the tenant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and for related damages.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely concerns adoption and enforcement of an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, not the traditional covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explains that constructive eviction (historically tied to quiet enjoyment) is no longer needed and that the tenant’s remedies—including reimbursement of rent and discomfort/annoyance damages—flow from breach of the implied warranty of habitability and contract principles, not from a covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case supports landlord liability for habitability-based damages, but not under the rubric of quiet enjoyment as stated in the proposition.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. … Because of our holding in this case, the doctrine of constructive eviction, wherein the tenant must abandon in order to escape liability for rent, is no longer viable. … Under our holding, when a landlord breaches the implied warranty of habitability, the tenant may withhold future rent, and may also seek damages in the amount of rent previously paid.

Edwards v. Habib, 397 A.2d 1049 (D.C. 19.proposition: A landlord who fails to maintain premises in a habitable condition and who fails to remedy conditions that substantially impair a tenant’s use and enjoyment may be liable to the tenant for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and for related damages.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Consumer Protec.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Consumer Protection Act) (relevant to landlord practices affecting tenants’ rights; illustrative authority)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Consumer Protec.proposition: The foregoing list includes controlling Massachusetts statutes and regulations and seminal judicial and secondary authorities describing and supporting the well-established legal principles governing landlord obligations regarding habitability, health and quiet enjoyment. Plaintiff relies on these authorities to support the legal theory that Defendant’s failure to remediate the mold and to correct inadequate ventilation constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
